title: 106_s220
content: The Trade Adjustment Assistance Improvements Act of 1999 is cited as the short title. Authorization of appropriations for consolidated trade adjustment assistance is amended under Section 245 of the Trade Act of 1974. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Improvements Act of 1999 authorizes appropriations to the Department of Labor for fiscal years 1999-2001. It includes a temporary extension of NAFTA assistance and repeals the NAFTA Transitional Adjustment Assistance Program. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Improvements Act of 1999 makes amendments to section 285 of the Act, terminating assistance under chapter 2 after September 30, 2001. The effective date for the amendments is July 1, 1999, or the date of enactment of the Act. The amendments made by subsection (b) of the Trade Adjustment Assistance Improvements Act of 1999 take effect on October 1, 1999, or 90 days after the date of enactment of the Act, whichever is later. SEC. 3. Filing of petitions and provision of rapid response assistance; expedited review by Secretary of Labor. Section 221(a) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow for the filing of petitions for certification of eligibility for adjustment assistance by various entities including workers, unions, employers, and state agencies on behalf of workers. Upon receipt of a petition filed under paragraph (1), the Governor shall transmit it to the Secretary of Labor, ensure rapid response assistance and basic readjustment services are available to the workers, and assist the Secretary in reviewing the petition. The Secretary will promptly publish notice in the Federal Register upon receiving the petition for investigation. Amendment to expedite review of petitions by Secretary of Labor from 60 days to 40 days. SEC. 4. ADDITION OF SHIFT IN PRODUCTION AS BASIS FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR TRADE ADJUSTMENT ASSISTANCE. Section 222(a) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to certify a group of workers as eligible for adjustment assistance if a significant number have become separated or are threatened to be separated, and if there is a decrease in sales or production, or an increase in imports of competitive articles. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to provide adjustment assistance to workers if there is a significant increase in imports that contributes to their separation or threat of separation, or if there is a shift in production to a foreign country. SEC. 5 amends the Trade Act of 1974 to require the Secretary to collect information on countries where firms have shifted production or imports have resulted in certifications. SEC. 6 addresses enrollment in training requirements. Section 231(a)(5)(A) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include new enrollment requirements for workers affected by adverse employment conditions. The enrollment must occur within specific timeframes after the worker's separation or certification by the Secretary. The Secretary may extend the enrollment period for workers affected by adverse employment conditions if extenuating circumstances are present. SEC. 7. WAIVERS OF TRAINING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary may waive the training requirement for a worker if it is not feasible or appropriate, based on factors such as potential recall by the firm or having marketable skills. The worker may be exempt from training if they are close to qualifying for old-age insurance benefits, unable to participate in training due to health reasons, and the training start date is within 45 days or delayed for valid reasons. The Secretary may waive training requirements if there are insufficient funds available, the training duration exceeds entitlements, and other federal or state programs cannot guarantee completion. The waiver duration will be specified and periodically reviewed by the Secretary. The Secretary may waive training requirements if funds are insufficient, training duration exceeds entitlements, and other programs cannot guarantee completion. The waiver will be periodically reviewed, and if no longer applicable, revoked. The Secretary can authorize States to carry out activities, excluding certain determinations, and must submit written statements and reasons for the waiver. An annual report identifying the number of workers receiving waivers and their average duration must be submitted to relevant committees. The average duration of waivers issued under this subsection in the preceding year is required. Section 231(a)(5)(C) of the Act is amended by removing "certified". SEC. 8 amends the Trade Act of 1974 to provide trade readjustment allowances for 30 days during breaks in training. SEC. 9 increases the annual total amount of payments for training to $150,000,000. SEC. 10 eliminates the quarterly report requirement. SEC. 11 coordinates with one-stop delivery systems, the Job Training Partnership Act, and the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. SEC. 11 of the Trade Act of 1974 coordinates with one-stop delivery systems, the Job Training Partnership Act, and the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 by amending relevant sections. The Trade Act of 1974 coordinates with other workforce programs by adding common reporting systems and elements for participant data and performance outcomes. SEC. 12. SUPPORTIVE SERVICES. Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to include supportive services under Part II of subchapter B of chapter 2 of title II. The Trade Act of 1974 has been amended to include provisions for supportive services for adversely affected workers. Workers covered by a certification can apply for services such as transportation and child care to enable them to participate in training programs. The Secretary may approve the application if it is necessary for the worker's training participation and consistent with other supportive services provided under the program for dislocated workers. The Trade Act of 1974 has been amended to include provisions for supportive services for adversely affected workers under the Partnership Act or the Workforce Investment Act. Amendments include inserting a new section in the table of contents. SEC. 13. Additional conforming amendments to the Trade Act of 1974, including changes to sections 225 and 240. SEC. 14. Availability of contingency funds. SEC. 14. Availability of contingency funds. Amends Section 245 of the Trade Act of 1974 to authorize the availability of funds from the Treasury if program funds are exhausted in a fiscal year. Effective date is July 1, 1999, or the date of enactment of the Act. SEC. 15. REAUTHORIZATION OF ADJUSTMENT ASSISTANCE FOR FIRMS. Amends Section 256(b) of the Trade Act of 1974 to extend the period for fiscal years 1999 through 2001. Effective date is July 1, 1999, or the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 16. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PROVISION. Specifies the effective date of the Act and amendments as October 1, 1999, or 90 days after enactment. Allows the Secretary of Labor to create necessary rules for implementation.
